Boreskov Institute of Catalysis SB RAS Covalent triazine frameworks (CTFs) are relatively novel materials and could be used as supports for single-atom metal catalysts (SACs), which attract a lot of interest during last years. The present review shows that CTFs are suitable supports for SACs for different reactions including oxidation, hydroformylation, O2 reduction, N2 fixation, CO2 photoreduction, hydrogen production, transfer and evolution. It discusses synthesis techniques and focuses on the structure of the obtained single-atom active sites including Pd, Ir, Ru, Rh, Pt, Ni, Co, Cu, and Fe atoms. It also considers some mechanisms of the mentioned reactions. The critical challenges and future perspectives for SACs based on CTFs are considered. This knowledge could be used as a base for design and engineering of single-atom active sites and will allow one to develop novel catalysts for different catalytic processes. Graphical Abstract Keywords Single-atom catalyst Covalent triazine frameworks Active site Molecular structure EXAFS Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction One of the important goals in studies of heterogeneous catalysis is increasing the efficiency of utilizing expensive noble metals. Thus, a great attention was paid to increasing the dispersion of supported metals. In contrast to traditional supported metal catalysts with nanoparticles, single-atom catalysts represent isolated metal atoms attached to specific sites of a catalyst’s support. As compared to supported molecular metal complexes, ligands initially present in these complexes are substituted by these specific sites. This provides a strong interaction with metal atoms usually present in cationic states, thus preventing their agglomeration and formation of nanoparticles leading to catalyst deactivation [1,2]. As a result, improved stability makes it possible to use single-atom catalysts at harsher conditions than those used for catalysts with supported nanoparticles or molecular complexes [3]. The attained 100 % dispersion implies utilizing of all atoms in metal loading for interaction with reactants providing a decrease in the catalyst’s cost. This is especially important for catalysts containing noble metals such as Pt, Pd, Ru etc. Improved catalytic properties of supported single-atom catalysts as compared to traditional heterogeneous catalysts with nanoparticles are related to the structure of active sites. The structure could be established using modern physico-chemical techniques. This allows researchers to understand deeper the mechanism of catalytic reactions at atomic and molecular levels thus bridging homogenous and heterogeneous catalysis. Understanding the structure and electronic properties of the single-atom site and mechanism of the reaction facilitates further improvement of a catalyst towards higher activity, selectivity and stability in a reaction [2,4]. The promising results were obtained recently in the field of single-atom catalysts used as thermal-, photo- and electro-catalysts [1,4–6]. Since the active site implies the presence of a single metal atom in a certain environment of support atoms [7,8], the choice of the support is very important to provide the formation of single-atom sites and their high catalytic performance. For example, studies related to N-doping of carbon support showed improved properties of a catalyst based on these supports in catalytic reactions as compared to N-free supports. One of the reasons for this could be the formation of single-atom metal sites stabilized by N species of the support [9–16]. However, the results for N-doped carbon supports showed that using traditional post-deposition of active metal from different salts does not allow preparing a single-atom catalyst with Pd or Pt content of higher than 0.3 wt% [12–14]. Increasing the concentration of metals provided an enhanced formation of metal nanoparticles. Therefore, reaching of high surface density of single-atom metal sites is an important task [17–20]. The nature and number of the surface support sites able to stabilize strongly metal atoms are crucial for the creation of efficient catalysts. Hence, novel high surface area materials containing N-sites attract attention. Among them covalent triazine frameworks (CTFs) [21–28] are considered to be a promising platform for design of heterogenous single-atom catalysts [29]. CTFs usually consist of carbon, nitrogen and hydrogen. The well-defined structure of nitrogen species involved into rigid conjugated aromatic network as well as high surface area and porosity with the opportunity to further tuning allow researchers to design highly efficient CTFs-based catalysts. Other also attractive properties are high thermal and chemical stability, high acid-base resistance as compared to other organic frameworks, the ability to anchor metal-loading in a highly stable state and finally the abundance of electron-rich nitrogen atoms, which may demonstrate synergistic catalytic effect in the presence of metal sites [30–32]. Besides high surface area and porosity, CTFs also possess Lewis basicity, which provides their strong interaction with some molecules. The exceptional performance of CTFs in capture and storage of small molecules is widely known [24,28,33–35]. Moreover, Li et al. [36] indicated that nanocomposites, containing CTFs, exhibit a wide-ranging spectrum of light absorption, well-suited electronic band structures, rapid charge carrier mobility, ample resource availability, commendable chemical robustness, and straightforward synthetic routes. These features allowed to consider them as highly promising photocatalysts with applicability in diverse fields. There are different methods of CTFs synthesis [21,25,26]. However, the traditional ionothermal synthesis of CTFs attracts the most attention. This synthesis performed at 673 K with ZnCl2 used as a solvent and catalyst with Lewis basic sites for polymerization of carbonitrile precursors should lead to the formation of a layered structure of CTFs ( Fig. 1) [37]. Yet, at higher temperatures (773 and 823 K) the structure of the obtained material is becoming more complex due to the processes of carbonization/amorphization which are difficult to avoid [21,23,38,39]. By varying the carbonitrile/ZnCl2 ratio, synthesis temperature and polymerization time, the contribution of these processes can be tuned [37,40,41]. At the same time, there are certain advantages of amorphous materials like a significant increase of the specific surface area and porosity (Fig. 1) [21,42] providing higher capacity to precursor metal salts [42] which could lead to a higher density of single-atom metal sites. An increased synthesis temperature higher than 873 K leads to a significant loss of N from CTFs samples with the formation of N-doped carbon materials accompanied by a decrease in the specific surface area at very high temperatures. There are a few review papers related to single-atom and molecular complexes catalysts supported on covalent organic frameworks (COFs) [43–45]. CTFs represent a sub-class of COFs, containing N-rich triazine linkages and demand a separate consideration related to their application as supports for catalysts and to the nature of the active sites. Some reviews [22,29] related to CTFs already discussed their application as catalysts supports, but mainly for molecular metal complexes and nanoparticles. Single-atom catalysts supported on CTFs demand a special attention. It turned out that if a few years ago there was no enough material for such a review, now it appeared. It indicates that this is a quickly developing field of research. In this review we discuss the reactions taking place over single-atom catalysts supported on CTFs, their synthesis methods and especially the structure of single-atom active site formed in CTFs. We do not discuss details of synthesis of CTFs materials, catalytic properties of metal-free CTFs, or CTFs with supported metal nanoparticles and metal complexes since some excellent reviews and research papers related to these subjects have already been published [21–24,27,28]. 2 Single-atom catalysts based on noble metals 2.1 Pd/CTFs catalysts Earlier, single-atom Pd catalysts were used for reactions of 1,3-butadiene [41,46,47] and acetylene hydrogenation [13,41,48,49], hydrogen production from formic acid [9,11,12], electrochemical H2O2 synthesis [50] and hydrogenation of organic compounds [51]. Zhang et al. [52] deposited 1.84 wt% Pd using a deposition-reduction method on a CTFs support synthesized by the Friedel–Crafts synthesis [53]. They obtained Pd nanoparticles with a mean size of 2.4 nm. It was not clear whether single Pd atoms were formed or not since the characterization of Pd in their catalysts was limited to X-ray diffraction (XRD) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) methods. Chan-Thaw et al. [54] designed efficient CTFs-based Pd catalysts for liquid phase glycerol oxidation. Glycerol is a by-product of the production of biodiesel through the transesterification of vegetable oil and animal fats. The glycerol production is increasing steadily and demands finding new routes for its application. The authors synthesized 1,4-dicyanobenzene derived CTFs support with a very high surface area of 2814 m2/g. This type of CTFs is denoted as CTF-1 [37]. The authors deposited 1 wt% of Pd from Na2PdCl4 by impregnation. They showed that neither the treatments by NaBH4 nor by H2 at elevated temperatures were able to reduce the existing Pd2+ species observed by XPS. These data could indicate to the presence of single-atom Pd2+ species which were stabilized by N species of the CTFs support. This is in accordance with the studies of single-atom Pd catalysts on N-doped carbon [11,55], where the authors were not able to convert Pd2+ species to Pd0 even at temperatures up to 773 K due to strong interaction of Pd species with pyridinic N sites of the support. As concerning the catalytic properties in glycerol oxidation, the catalyst with Pd2+ species showed a lower conversion of glycerol and a lower selectivity to glyceric acid than those for the reference catalyst with Pd nanoparticles (3.1 nm) prepared by sol immobilization of metal nanoparticles stabilized by polyvinyl alcohol. However, the former catalyst was much more stable in the reaction. This could be provided by a confinement and stronger interaction of single Pd atoms with N sites of the CTFs support preventing leaching and/or agglomeration of Pd. The authors showed for the catalyst prepared by a sol immobilization that Pd was not able to move into the CTFs structure due to the presence of micropores of the support (< 2 nm). Thus, the nanoparticles were located on the external surface of the support. This enhanced deactivation during the reaction provided by leaching of the metal. In accordance with the results of Chan-Thaw et al. [54], Zhai et al. [56] obtained a 10 wt% Pd/CTFs catalyst with Pd nanoparticles and single Pd atoms. They regulated the ratio of single Pd atoms and Pd nanoparticles by changing reduction time in hydrogen at 573 K and used 2,6-pyridinedicarbonitrile-derived covalent triazine framework as a support and an aqueous solution of palladium trifluoroacetate as a precursor for Pd. They found that the optimal ratio of single Pd atoms and Pd nanoparticles is needed to obtain high reaction rates in hydrogenation of CO2 to formate by hydrogen. Finally, they supposed that nanoparticles activate hydrogen molecules while single Pd atoms activate carbon dioxide molecules for the reaction ( Fig. 2). As a result, the authors obtained the formate formation rate equal to 3.66 molHCOOM /(molPd×h) for the optimized catalyst. Developing of catalysts for production and storage of eco-friendly energy is essential for a sustainable society. Formic acid is a liquid organic hydrogen carrier and catalysts for its decomposition at low temperatures are needed. Formic acid could be obtained from biomass by hydrolysis/oxidation [57,58] or from CO2 by hydrogenation [56,58–60]. In contrast to the above-mentioned studies, Bulushev et al. [38] managed to synthesize Pd/CTFs single-atom catalysts. Using a simple impregnation method, the authors deposited Pd(acac)2 on CTF-1, pyCTFs and bipyCTFs supports ( Fig. 3) derived from 1,4-dicyanobenzene, 2,5-dicyanopyridine, and 5,5′-dicyano-2,2′-bipyridine monomers, respectively. The reductive treatment of the samples was performed under reaction conditions (573 K, HCOOH) to obtain 1 wt% Pd/CTFs catalysts. The authors used 3 methods to demonstrate the presence of single-atom Pd sites: High-Angle Annular Dark-Field/Scanning Transmission Electron Microscopy (HAADF/STEM), X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS) and Extended X-ray Absorption Fine Structure/Near Edge X-Ray Absorption Fine Structure Spectroscopy (EXAFS/XANES). A HAADF/STEM study revealed the abundance of Pd single-atoms and their uniform distribution on the support surface (Fig. 3). According to XPS and XANES data only ionic Pd2+ was present after the reductive treatment. This indicates that Pd atoms were strongly bound to the support sites and electron transfer occurred to the support to increase their stability. The authors studied the structure of active sites using EXAFS combined with modeling and concluded that a Pd atom in Pd/pyCTFs and Pd/bipyCTFs is coordinated by four nitrogen atoms forming the Pd2+-N4 site with the Pd-N distance of 2.04 Å ( Fig. 4), while that in Pd/CTF-1 is stabilized by two carbon and two nitrogen atoms forming a Pd-C2N2 site with the Pd-C and Pd-N distances of 2.05 and 2.09 Å, respectively. A four-fold coordination of the Pd atom implies interaction with two CTFs sheets since it is difficult to imagine such a coordination with a single CTFs unit. The authors studied their catalysts in gas-phase hydrogen production from formic acid. The Pd-C2N2 active sites provided high specific catalytic activity and stability in production of hydrogen from gas-phase formic acid outperforming the reference Pd/C catalyst (dNP ∼2.3 nm) by a factor of 1.7 at 398 K (Fig. 3). The hydrogen production selectivity was also higher and corresponded to 97–98 % at 490–570 K. Prolonged catalytic tests (5 h) showed an excellent stability of the Pd/CTF-1 catalyst, while the activity of Pd/C decreased by a factor of 1.3. Later, the same group studied two other Pd catalysts based on acacCTFs and hatnCTFs prepared from malonyldibenzonitrile and hexaazatrinaphthylenetricarbonitrile, respectively [61]. An EXAFS study confirmed the presence of Pd2+-O4 sites and Pd nanoparticles in a close ratio for Pd/acacCTFs, while the presence of Pd2+-C1N3 single-atom sites and few-atom Pd clusters for Pd/hatnCTFs. The former catalyst demonstrated a low activity, but also a low apparent activation energy, which could indicate that only nanoparticles were active in the reaction, but single-atom Pd-O4 sites could be only low active. At the same time, the activity of the Pd/hatnCTFs catalyst was even higher than that of the Pd/CTF-1 catalyst at high temperatures and exceeded significantly the activity of a Pd catalyst supported on graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4) with the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area equal to 84 m2/g containing single-atom Pd sites and Pd nanoparticles (∼ 3.0 nm). Hence, the nature of CTFs support, Pd deposition method and reduction procedure are important for the formation of single Pd atoms and Pd nanoparticles in the catalysts supported on CTFs. Some single-atom Pd catalysts provide a higher activity, selectivity and stability in some reactions as compared to Pd catalysts with nanoparticles. 2.2 Ir/CTFs catalysts The group of Palkovits [62] studied Ir/CTFs catalysts in liquid-phase formic acid decomposition reaction at 433 K. They performed a synthesis of a 1 wt% Ir catalyst by wet impregnation in ethanol using (Acetylacetonato)-(1,5-Cyclooctadiene)-Iridium(I) (Ir(acac)(COD)) on a CTF-1 support prepared by polycondensation of diamidine and alcohol. The authors tested the catalysts after different reduction treatments ( Fig. 5a). Before the reduction single Ir metal complex sites were observed in the HAADF/STEM image (Fig. 5b). The reduction treatment performed at temperatures lower than 673 K led to removal of ligands from Ir atoms and formation of a single-atom catalyst (Fig. 5c). The structure of the active single-atom site was determined by EXAFS to correspond to Ir-C2N2. The Ir-C(N) distances in the Ir-C2N2 site corresponded to 2.04 Å. The sample containing these sites formed in H2 at 673 K exhibited the highest turnover frequency for the hydrogen formation (TOF=24,400 h−1) as compared to the non-reduced sample (TOF=16,900 h−1), reference 5 wt% Ir/C catalyst with nanoparticles and dispersion of 33 % (TOF=1500 h−1) and different complexes containing Ir. The hydrogen selectivity and stability for the single-atom catalyst were also high. However, the comparison with the data for the Pd single-atom catalysts used in the gas-phase hydrogen production from formic acid is complicated due to different conditions of the reaction (liquid-phase vs. gas-phase). The formation of the Ir-C2N2 site could also imply an interaction of the Ir atom with two CTFs sheets. The authors performed Density Functional Theory (DFT) calculations of the optimal structure corresponding to the Ir atom in CTFs and interaction of formic acid with such an active site [63]. However, as they noted, the comparability of computational and experimental results was rather weak. The calculated energy barriers were too high corresponding to 163 and 182 kJ/mol for the formic acid dehydrogenation via carboxyl and formate routes, respectively. These values were not able to explain the experimental reaction turnover frequencies. The authors assigned this result to neglecting a solvent in calculations. At temperatures higher than 673 K the CTFs support starts to decompose and Ir clusters and nanoparticles were formed (Fig. 5d) [62]. According to XPS (Ir4f7/2) data the shifts of the binding energy to lower values for reduced samples are observed indicating concentration of electron density at metal sites. This behavior can be attributed to removing of electron-withdrawing ligands as well as to the formation of new bonds with electron-donating nitrogen sites of the support. Such an electron transfer model agreed with NEXAFS data, which demonstrated an increased intensity of the main resonance π*1, C N-C that leads to higher probability of the N1s– π* transition and σ-donation from the nitrogen lone pair to the Ir d-orbital. Therefore, the presented studies of a single-atom Ir catalyst demonstrated an excellent catalytic performance and stability in hydrogen atmosphere as compared to supported and unsupported molecular Ir complexes and supported Ir nanoparticles. 2.3 Ru/CTFs catalysts Ruthenium is a rare transition metal belonging to the platinum group. This metal is often used for conversion of biomass derived compounds to valuable chemicals. This metal can be also easily stabilized on N-rich CTFs supports. Artz et al. studied catalytic properties of Ru/CTFs samples in oxidation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural, which is a biomass platform molecule, to 2,5-furandicarboxilic acid (FDCA) [64] and to 2,5-diformylfuran (DFF) [40]. They synthesized CTFs materials using 1,3-dicyanobenzene (CTF-a), 2,6-pyridinedicarbonitrile (CTF-b), 1,4-dicyanobenzene (CTF-c), and 4,4’-biphenyldicarbonitrile (CTF-d) ( Fig. 6a). The authors deposited Ru using a RuCl3×xH2O salt solution. In their works Artz et al. [40,64] did not present a clear evidence of the existence of single atom Ru sites in their CTFs based catalysts. However, after the treatment in hydrogen at 623 K TEM and XRD did not find Ru nanoparticles. These data could indicate to the presence of such single Ru atoms stabilized by the support. At conversions of 90–100 % the selectivity order in the formation of FDCA for the Ru catalysts was the following: 3.9 wt% Ru/CTF-c (41.1 %) > 4.3 wt% Ru/CTF-a (37.7 %) > 4.0 wt% Ru/CTF-d (33.4 %) > 3.3 wt% Ru/CTF-b (8.2 %) [64]. The CTF-b support contained micropores, while other supports were mainly mesoporous. The authors concluded that porosity, specific surface area and hydrophilicity of the support are important for the catalytic performance. The Ru/CTF-c catalyst demonstrated also high stability in the reaction as compared to the reference 5 wt% Ru/C catalyst indicating its resistance to leaching of Ru. At the same conditions a Ru/γ-Al2O3 catalyst showed low conversions and did not yield FDCA. At lower conversions, 5-hydroxymethylfurfural was oxidized to 2,5-diformylfuran [40]. The authors studied an effect of the nature of the support on the reaction and showed a high performance of the 4.3 wt% Ru/CTF-a catalyst as compared to Ru/γ-Al2O3, Ru/C, Ru/MgO and Ru/hydrotalcite catalysts. Up to 63.6 % selectivity was reached at 86.3 % conversion at 20 bar of air and 353 K. The microporous Ru/CTF-b catalyst was almost inactive at these conditions, while Ru supported on other CTFs materials showed slightly lower conversions than those for Ru/CTF-a (Fig. 6b). Again, these data support the importance of high surface area and porosity of CTFs for high activity. Zhang et al. [41] applied another technique for synthesis of a CTFs-derived single-atom catalyst. A CTFs support prepared using 2,6-dicyanopyridine was mixed with acetonitrile followed by heating at reflux with CH3I at 353 K for 24 h. An aqueous solution of K4[Ru(CN)6] was used with I--containing CTFs to deposit Ru metal complexes by ion-exchange reaction, then the sample was calcined at 1173 K. Thus, the authors prepared a 0.8 % Ru/CTF-I catalyst to further compare its properties with a 1.2 % Ru/CTFs catalyst obtained via conventional heating at 1173 K without any pretreatment. According to XPS data (Ru3p3/2) a mixture of Ruδ+ and Ru0 was detected for Ru/CTFs with a significantly higher content of Ru0. This was confirmed by EXAFS and XANES, since the reference Ru foil profile approximated the spectrum obtained with determined Ru-Ru coordination number of 7.2, which means that Ru was sintered into clusters. In contrast, the predominance of Ruδ+ coordinated by 3 nitrogen atoms was demonstrated for the Ru/CTF-I sample. HAADF/STEM images revealed the abundance of Ru single-atoms, however the nanoparticles with a mean size of < 5 nm could be also found in the sample. The authors attributed this difference to robust Ru-support electrovalent interaction, which provided high stability of Ru species during calcination. A charge-modulated strategy allows I- ions to be substituted by [Ru(CN)6]4- ions with the formation of bonds between positively charged nitrogen sites of CTFs support and negatively charged Ru complex preventing high mobility of metal atoms due to electrostatic repulsion and steric hindrance. Finally, these authors [41] tested the catalyst in transfer hydrogenation of acetophenone by isopropanol to produce 1-phenylethanol. According to the data obtained the Ru/CTF-I sample demonstrated an enhanced catalytic activity providing high yields, which could reach 74.8 % at 393 K as compared to 28.1 % for other Ru/CTFs. The authors claimed that high nitrogen content in CTFs does not provide necessary bonding effect by itself during calcination at high temperature, while ion-exchange strategy with strong electrovalent bonding and high resistance to agglomeration allows one to obtain atomically dispersed metal catalysts. Hence, the data for Ru clearly demonstrated a higher activity of single-atom catalysts, however, porosity, specific surface area and hydrophilicity of the support could be also important for the catalytic performance. 2.4 Rh/CTFs catalysts Homogeneous Rh catalysts are applied for hydroformylation reaction to produce aldehydes from alkenes. The produced aldehydes could be used further for production of detergents, fragrances and pharmaceuticals. It would be useful to substitute homogeneous catalysts based on carbonyl containing metal complexes with single-atom heterogeneous catalysts. Pilaski et al. [65] used the same precursors (Fig. 6a) to synthesize CTFs at temperatures 673–873 K. They took a rhodium(III) chloride hydrate to deposit Rh at concentrations between 3.4 and 5.0 wt%. An EXAFS study was performed to elucidate the local structure of the Rh sites. The RhCl3/CTF-a sample contained four Rh-N bonds and two Rh-Cl bonds like in an unsupported [Rh(py)4Cl2]Cl complex. For the catalyst treated in hydrogen at 523 K the contribution from the Rh-Cl bonds disappeared, but four Rh-N distances became slightly shorter (2.05 Å). Thus, a single-atom Rh catalyst with Rh-N4 sites was formed. No Rh-Rh contribution was found in the EXAFS spectra excluding the formation of Rh nanoparticles. However, some nanoparticles with a size of 1.8–2.4 nm were still observed by high resolution TEM, but they were not the main species. The authors tested the catalysts in hydroformylation of 1-octene giving the production of nonanal and 2-methyloctanal at 80 bar of CO/H2 (1:1) mixture and 353 K. The highest activity was demonstrated by the Rh/CTF-a catalyst. The Rh/CTF-b catalyst showed the lowest activity which was explained by a microporous nature and high polarity of the support. The Rh/CTF-a, -c and -d catalysts demonstrated a comparable product distribution providing the selectivity for nonanal at about 42 %, while that for the Rh/C catalyst was lower (33 %). Some gradual decrease in the activity was observed for all catalysts in recyclability studies within 5 runs. Finally, the authors made a conclusion that their catalytic systems based on CTFs were very active and much more resistant to leaching than other heterogeneous catalysts for this reaction. This opens good perspectives for single-atom catalysts to be used instead of homogeneous catalysts in hydrogenation reactions. In accordance, Chinese researchers [66] reported recently that a chemical plant was put into operation in China, producing propanol from ethylene in the scale of 50,000 ton/year using a single Rh atom catalyst. 2.5 Pt/CTFs catalysts Pt containing molecular complexes supported on CTFs were intensively studied in different fields of catalysis [67–70]. According to EXAFS studies they normally contain Pt-N2Cl2 structural units due to using of K2PtCl4 as a Pt precursor. A reduction of such materials in hydrogen to remove Cl ligands and to prepare catalysts which contain single Pt atoms attached to N sites of the CTFs support is often needed. Thus, Li et al. [71] showed that 1 wt% Pt can be obtained in atomically dispersed form using CTFs nanosheets. The main steps of synthesis were impregnation of the support with a K2PtCl4 aqueous solution followed by stirring, drying and reduction in an H2/Ar mixture at 453 K. A HAADF/STEM image ( Fig. 7a) revealed the absence of nanoparticles. In contrast, the Pt loading was homogeneously dispersed over the support in the form of single atoms (Fig. 7 a, b). The electronic state of Pt was established using XPS. Comparing the as-prepared sample with reference PtO2 and Pt foil samples, the authors noted the transfer of electrons from the Pt atom to the CTFs framework through nitrogen atoms leading to positively charged Ptδ+ species with 0 < δ < +2. For further confirmation of the nature of active site an EXAFS study was performed. A sharp peak at 1.57 Å (without phase correction) indicated a strong interaction of the Pt atom with nitrogen atoms. A minor peak at 2.38 Å could be ascribed to the Pt-C(N) second coordination shell rather than to the Pt-Pt interaction, which can be observed at 2.34 Å for Pt foil, since the wavelet transform EXAFS demonstrated only a negligible signal of the Pt-Pt bond for the Pt/CTFs catalyst, while for PtO2 and Pt foil that was clearly observed. Combining DFT-calculations with EXAFS data the authors suggested the structure of the Pt active site as the Pt atom anchored to three nitrogen atoms forming a Pt-N3 site with DFT-optimized bond lengths of 2.02, 2.07 and 2.07 Å (Fig. 7c). The application of the photocatalytic N2 reduction to NH3 at normal reaction conditions is known, but the real-world application of such procedure is restricted due to low productivity of the catalysts [6]. Therefore, the Li et al. [71] performed photocatalytic N2 fixation experiments with their catalysts in the N2-saturated water under the visible light irradiation at room temperature. As a result, ammonia was produced and transformed to NH4 + ions. The rates were by a factor of 1.5 higher than those with the catalyst, which contained Pt nanoparticles. The production of ammonia was stable during 5 catalytic cycles with each cycle duration of 5 h. These authors proposed a reaction mechanism for the reaction N2 + 6 H+ + 6e− → 2NH3 based on DFT calculations ( Fig. 8). The mechanism involves adsorption of the N2 molecule on the Pt-N3 site, consecutive protonation of this molecule with the formation of the NH2NH2 intermediate followed by desorption of the NH3 molecule. Huang et al. [72] upgraded techniques for synthesis of CTFs-derived Pt single-atom catalyst using ethylene glycol (EG) stabilized frameworks. 1,4-dicyanobenzene was used as a precursor to obtain a CTF-1 support. After heating at 423 K of the suspension of CTF-1 in EG, a gray solid obtained was dispersed in water followed by addition of a H2PtCl6 solution, irradiation by ultraviolet lamp and washing for Cl- removing, which was facilitated by the presence of EG. The role of the EG-additive was studied by carrying out the same synthesis with distilled water substituting EG. HAADF/STEM measurements demonstrated the abundance of single-atom Pt in Pt/CTF-EG, while nanoparticles with a size of 10–50 nm can be found in Pt/CTF-H2O. XPS Pt4f spectra of Pt/CTF-EG mainly coincided with the data reported by Li et al. [71] and could be assigned to partially oxidized Ptδ+ state with 0 < δ < 2, while the presence of Pt2+ species mainly observed for Pt/CTF-H2O indicated to the predominance of PtO particles. In opposite to the previous report, modeling of the EXAFS data led to the Pt-NC2 structure of the active site with the Pt-N and Pt-C distances equal to 2.00 and 1.92 Å, respectively. However, the main advantage of the three-coordinated Pt single-atom was remained as the empty sp3 orbital was left making the active site suitable for adsorption of molecules. The authors demonstrated that their single-atom Pt/CTF-1 catalyst exhibited high activity in photoreduction of CO2 to CH4. The rate for this reaction was 4 times higher than that of the Pt/CTF-1 catalyst with nanoparticles. And the selectivity was by a factor of 1.7 higher. In addition, the catalyst was stable through consecutive five test cycles. The improved catalytic properties were assigned to excellent CO2 adsorption capability in the presence of light irradiation. It is interesting that in both studies for Pt/CTFs unsaturated three-, but not four-coordinated Pt single-atom sites were determined. These catalysts demonstrated high activity in photocatalytic reactions of CO2 conversion to methane and N2 conversion to NH3. It could be expected that these catalysts could be promising for many thermal catalytic reactions. 3 Single-atom catalysts based on non-noble metals 3.1 Ni/CTFs catalysts Substitution of Pt-group metal catalysts with cheap non-noble metal catalysts is an important task. The problem of non-noble metal catalysts with nanoparticles is their low resistance to leaching and agglomeration. Single-atom metal sites are often more stable than nanoparticles. Ni is known for its ability to form single-atom sites with different structure depending on synthesis method and support used [73]. These catalysts were used for a wide set of reactions. Using DFT calculations Gong et al. [74] identified the coordinatively unsaturated Ni-doped covalent triazine framework (Ni/CTFs) as one of the best electrocatalysts with the lowest overpotential (0.34 V) for CO2 reduction toward CO while the formation of side products included hydrogen and formic acid was inhibited. As opposite to post-synthetic methods discussed above, Lu et al. [75] performed an ionothermal synthesis using a non-conventional Ni-containing CTFs-precursor (5,10,15,20-tetrakis(4-cyanophenyl) porphyrin nickel). A HAADF/STEM study of a 2.4 wt% Ni/CTFs catalyst demonstrated the formation of atomically dispersed Ni sites. The Ni-N4 structure of the active site with the Ni-N bond distance corresponding to 1.85 Å was determined based on EXAFS data. XPS Ni2p spectra indicated the presence of Ni2+ single atoms coordinated by four nitrogen sites of a porphyrin unit ( Fig. 9). The obtained catalyst showed high selectivity of the CO formation in electrochemical CO2 reduction with a Faradaic efficiency of > 90 % over the range from −0.6 to −0.9 V for CO2 conversion and good long-term stability. Yang and co-authors [76] developed a new synthesis of a Ni catalyst based on crystalline CTFs catalyst, which was obtained using trimerization of amidine-type monomers in the presence of ZnCl2 and NiCl2. The mixture was heated at 573–623 K and then at 1073 K. As a result, Ni-CN3 single-atom sites were obtained. The Ni-N and Ni-C distances corresponded to 1.86 and 2.11 Å, respectively. The catalyst showed efficient behavior in electrochemical CO2 reduction to CO. Liu and co-authors [77] synthesized a single-atom Ni catalyst supported on triazine deficient CTFs prepared from a mixture of 1,4-dicyanobenzene with 4-cyanopyridine and trifluoromethanesulfonic superacid (TfOH). BET surface areas of their catalysts and supports were reported to be surprisingly low (<1.1 m2/g). A nickel nitrate salt solution was used to deposit 0.23 wt% Ni. Characterization by EXAFS indicated that Ni coordinates about 2 atoms of nitrogen (2.2) in the first coordination sphere with the Ni-N distances corresponding to 1.89 Å. The catalyst was tested in photocatalytic O2 reduction reaction giving H2O2. The results were compared with a 0.51 wt% Ni containing sample, for which the CTFs support was prepared without 4-cyanopyridine addition. This sample contained nanoparticles except of single-atom sites. The catalyst prepared with the triazine deficient support demonstrated much higher yields of H2O2 in water (869.1 μmol/(g×h)) and excellent stability. The authors indicated importance of the presence of nitrogen pyridinic sites of the support and of the Ni-N2 sites for the reaction. Experimental and quantum chemical calculations showed that the electron deficiency of N atom in pyridine type species of CTFs promotes hole accumulation, while the single Ni atom provides a directional pathway (Ni → O2) for electron transfer ( Fig. 10). Therefore, a bifunctional nature of the Ni/CTFs catalyst is used and leads to acceleration of the reaction. It should be mentioned that the H2O2 production is presently performed using the anthraquinone process, which involves the application and generation of hazardous substances. Su et al. [78] synthesized CTFs via the polymerization of 2,6-dicyanopyridine in the presence of conductive carbon particles. The authors deposited Ni from a NiCl2 salt solution. A study of the 0.17 at% Ni/CTFs sample by EXAFS demonstrated that Ni existed in the form of single atoms attached to N species of the CTFs support. The average coordination number was calculated to be 3.4 and the Ni-N distance 2.08 Å. According to XPS study the state of Ni corresponded to 2+. The sample showed high activity in CO2 electrochemical reduction. The Faradaic efficiency of Ni/CTF during CO formation reached 90 % at −0.8 V versus reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE). The performance of Ni/CTFs was much better than that of the corresponding Ni-tetraphenylporphyrin with the Ni-N4 sites and Ni-N distances equal to 1.94 Å. Therefore, single-atom Ni sites supported on CTFs can be obtained in different coordination with respect to neighboring N and C atoms (2, 3 and 4). This opens the ways for optimizing catalytic properties of Ni sites for different reactions. 3.2 Co/CTFs catalysts Single-atom Co catalysts are probably most studied catalysts among non-noble metal catalysts based on CTFs. Su et al. [78] also prepared a 0.13 at% Co/CTFs catalyst in the same way as the Ni/CTFs catalyst and reported the formation of the similar structure of a single-atom active site. The coordination number was found to be 3.2 and the Co-N distance 2.00 Å. The activity of this catalyst in CO2 electrochemical reduction was comparable to that for Ni/CTFs discussed above. Co/CTFs single-atom catalysts were intensively studied in photocatalytic reactions. Huang et al. [79] deposited Co on a CTF-1 from Co(NO3)2 with the content of Co up to 0.3 wt% in the samples. They performed a reduction using ultraviolet irradiation in an N2 flow. HAADF/STEM images clearly indicated that Co was present in the form of single atom species. The obtained single-atom Co/CTFs catalysts demonstrated a higher activity in photocatalytic CO2 reduction to CO (1665.74 μmol/(g×h)) and H2 evolution (1293.18 μmol/(g×h)) than those for the CTFs support and Co/CTFs catalyst with nanoparticles (∼10 nm). Since the structure of the Co sites was not tested using EXAFS, the nature of Co single-atom sites was left unclear, but a four-fold coordination to N sites could be supposed basing on XPS studies. The peaks in XPS Co2p spectra of 0.1 wt% Co/CTFs corresponded well to the peaks of phthalocyanine cobalt (II), indicating that Co was in the 2+ state. Jana et al. [80] prepared single-atom Co/CTFs catalysts also for photocatalytic CO2 reduction to CO. In this work, the CTFs material was synthesized by addition of tetra(4-cyanophenyl)ethylene into a mixture of dichloromethane and TfOH followed by sonication. The authors applied CoCl2 as a Co precursor. Clusters were not found in HRTEM images of this catalyst. In EXAFS spectra, the presence of the Co-Co bond was not observed for the 3.1 wt% Co catalyst. Single-atom Co sites were present in the 2+ oxidation state. However, the coordination number of the Co atom to N or C atoms was not reported. The authors obtained CO in the amount of 1515 µmol/g during 2 h of the run. Ma and co-authors [81] prepared Co porphyrin-based CTFs with Co content of 5–6 wt% using two approaches. Using the first approach they trimerized aromatic nitrile monomers applying a Brønsted superacid synthesis with TfOH, while using the second approach an ionothermal synthesis at high temperatures (773 K) with ZnCl2 was used. The photocatalytic activity of the former catalyst in the CO2 photoreduction to CO noticeably exceeded that for the latter catalyst. The reaction rate reached 2562.8 μmol/(g×h). The state of Co corresponded to only Co2+ ions in the case of synthesis using TfOH and to Co (II) and Co(0) species in the case of ionothermal synthesis. Chen et al. [82] anchored 0.87 wt% of Co atoms on a 2D-layered CTF-1 support. After impregnation of the support with Co(NO3)2 and pyrolysis at 573 K, they measured EXAFS spectra and assigned their data to the formation of a Co-N3 trigonal structure perpendicular to the nanosheets plane which could involve positively charged Co2+ ions and three nitrogen atoms of the single triazine unit with the Co-N distances of 2.07 Å. Here, it would be useful to confirm the stability of the proposed trigonal Co-N3 structure by DFT calculations. The authors used this catalyst for oxidative photoconversion of organic pollutants (organic dye, antibiotics and humic acid) in H2O2. The pollutants could be converted faster than over the CTF-1 support without metal. Thus, the methylene blue conversion increased from 69 % to 100 % and was stable. Single Co atoms served as oxidation centers to improve the visible-light harvesting ability, the migration of photo-generated electron and separation of charges. Recently, Zhu et al. [83] used a single-atom Co/CTFs catalyst for the photocatalytic production of H2O2 under visible light irradiation in O2-saturated pure water without any sacrificial reagent. The catalyst demonstrated an excellent H2O2 generation rate (2898.3 μmol/(h×g)) and selectivity (96.2 %). A pyCTFs support was synthesized via a ligand engineering strategy, involving the self-assembly of 1,4-dicyanobenzene and 2,6-pyridinedicarbonitrile. The content of Co in the catalyst corresponded to 3.27 wt%. Cobalt was deposited using Co(NO3)2×6 H2O. The presence of single Co atoms in a Co-N3 structure was confirmed by TEM and EXAFS. The average Co-N distances corresponded to 2.27 Å. It is interesting that under light irradiation the coordination of the Co atom did not change, but the Co-N distances increased to 2.59 Å. However, under light irradiation and O2 bubbling the formation of the Co-Co (2.67 Å) and Co-O (1.96 Å) bonds was established while one Co-N bond from every Co atom was broken and other Co-N bonds became longer (3.36 Å). Thus, during the reaction the formation of a novel active site took place. Evidently, the transformation of the structure of single-atom sites during the catalytic reactions should be considered ( Fig. 11). Yi et al. [84] formed single-atom Co in porphyrinic triazine frameworks. They synthesized the catalysts by pyrolysis of a mixture of 5,10,15,20-tetrakis(4-cyanophenyl)porphyrin with cobalt chloride at 673, 773 and 873 K with Co contents of 5.15 wt%, 2.74 wt% and 0.85 wt%, respectively. BET surface areas of the catalysts corresponded to the range from 562 to 741 m2/g. The formation of single Co atoms was confirmed using HAADF/STEM and EXAFS. The latter method combined with modelling indicated that Co-N4 active sites were formed with the Co-N distances of 1.9 Å ( Fig. 12). The obtained single-atom catalysts were highly active in electrocatalytic oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and hydrogen evolution reaction (HER). For the former reaction, a more positive half-wave potential of 0.808 V (vs. RHE) was achieved, compared with that for commercial Pt/C (0.806 V). For the latter reaction, a small onset potential of 21 mV and a low Tafel slope of 50 mV per decade were obtained. The catalyst prepared at 873 K showed the best performance in the reactions due to the following features: (1) the presence of accessible atomically dispersed active Co–N4 species; (2) high porosity providing the contact of reactive species with the active sites; (3) high conductivity improving the electron transfer capacity; (4) the presence of porphyrin-like anchoring sites stabilizing single-atom Co sites possessing a positive charge over the stable triazine-based frameworks, which provide high durability. Summarizing, single-atom Co catalysts supported on CTFs demonstrated the formation of Co-N3 and Co-N4 sites. For the former sites the Co-N bond distance can differ significantly from 2.0 to 2.27 Å. This could be provided by the synthesis method and could be used for evaluation of the effect of the Co-N bond length on catalytic properties. These catalysts may demonstrate good performance in liquid phase selective oxidation reactions since Co single-atom catalysts are known to be used for these reactions [85]. 3.3 Cu/CTFs catalysts Several studies were devoted to Cu single-atom catalysts supported on CTFs [86–88]. Xiong et al. [88] used a microwave-enhanced high-temperature ionothermal method for synthesis of CTFs from dicyanobenzene. Such technique allowed the authors to obtain CTFs with high BET surface area (1150 m2/g) in 6 min, while a traditional thermal heating is usually performed for 2–8 h. For Cu deposition a post-synthetic method via impregnation with CuCl2 was used. The coexistence of 2D-nanoflakes and 3D bulk structures with uniformly dispersed nitrogen and copper atoms was established using atomic force microscopy and energy-dispersive X-ray elemental mapping. The ionic Cu2+ state and strong Cu-N interaction with electron transfer were confirmed by XPS in Cu2p and N1s regions. This was consistent with the absence of Cu nanoparticles in TEM images. The authors tested the catalyst in H2O2-induced photooxidation of 3,3’,5,5’-tetramethylbenzidine (TMB). The catalyst exhibited high stability and enhanced catalytic activity reminding peroxidase-like activity, which can be compared with noble metal catalysts. However, despite the authors indicated that Cu was present in the form of single atoms, Cu containing nanoparticles were seen in their TEM images and demonstrated a shoulder in XPS Cu2p3/2 spectra. Iwase et al. [87] prepared their CTFs from 2,6-dicyanopyridine hybridized with carbon particles similarly as in their earlier work for Pt complexes [69]. They deposited Cu from copper chloride. The authors showed that the introduced carbon particles did not interact with CuCl2. The content of Cu in the sample determined by XPS corresponded to 0.58 at%. The authors did not find Cu nanoparticles in significant concentration in their samples. All Cu was present in the form of single atoms stabilized by N species of CTFs. Cu2+ species were dominant in the sample. According to EXAFS data the coordination number of Cu to N species was smaller than 4. This unsaturated coordination was probably a reason for high activity of the sample in electrocatalytic oxygen reduction reaction. Thus, the ORR onset potential of the synthesized Cu/CTFs sample was 810 mV versus RHE at pH=7. This value was probably the highest value for Cu-based electrocatalysts at neutral pH. In accordance, Cu-N4 species in Cu porphyrins or Cu phthalocyanines were only low active in this reaction. Modelling of the EXAFS spectra would be useful to establish the structure of the Cu-Nx sites. Yoshioka et al. [86] synthesized CTFs using ionothermal synthesis with 2,6-dicyanopyridine at 673 K. They also deposited Cu from copper chloride. An EXAFS study demonstrated that the Cu coordination number with respect to N atoms corresponded to 3.4 and the Cu-N distance to 2.01 Å. This indicates that Cu atoms possess open coordination for interaction with different molecules. The authors showed that these sites efficiently catalyze the electrochemical reduction of nitrate and execute the N−N bond formation in the form of N2O, which is a key intermediate for the further N2 formation. Thus, a Cu-CTF electrode exhibited an onset potential of −50 mV versus RHE for the electrochemical nitrate reduction reaction (NRR). The Faradaic efficiency for N2O formation reached 18 % at −200 mV versus RHE. These results could become possible due to a strong interaction of nitrate with the single-atom Cu site. The authors compared the mechanism of the reaction for the single-atom Cu-CTF catalyst and bulk Cu catalyst ( Fig. 13a). The Cu sites in Cu-CTF bind NO more strongly than Cu bulk metal, due to the coordinatively unsaturated nature of the Cu sites in Cu-CTF. Some NO molecules remained adsorbed on the Cu sites in Cu-CTF, while most of NO molecules generated in the reaction diffuse into the electrolyte. Thus, the solvated and surface-bound NO species react together on single Cu sites in Cu-CTF to form N2O (Fig. 13b). In bulk Cu metal the number of defective low coordinated sites is small. Huang and co-authors [89] constructed single-atom Cu/CTF-1 catalysts with Cu-NC2 sites for CO2 photoreduction to CO. The Cu-N distance was determined to be 1.917 Å and the Cu-C distance to 1.996 Å. Wet impregnation combined with ultraviolet reduction was used to deposit Cu from a copper nitrate aqueous solution. The content of Cu was relatively small (0.05–0.3 wt%). These catalysts demonstrated high CO selectivity of 98.3 %. Cu single-atom sites supported on CTFs showed promising catalytic properties in different electro- and photocatalytic reactions. We believe that they can be used also in some thermal catalytic reactions at low temperatures. 3.4 Fe/CTFs catalysts Iron is a very cheap and abundant metal and it attracts researchers to test it in catalytic reactions. Su and co-authors [90] prepared a Fe-containing catalyst on CTFs 2D-nanoflakes synthesized from dicyanobenzene by microwave-enhanced high-temperature ionothermal method as was earlier used for synthesis of the Cu/CTFs catalysts [88]. They loaded Fe from a FeCl3 solution. Energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy indicated a Fe content of 8.3 wt% in the sample. The formation of nanoparticles was not observed by TEM and XRD. XPS N1s spectra before and after Fe-anchoring via impregnation revealed a 0.6 eV shift of the peak of pyrrolic-like nitrogen to lower binding energies, while the peak of triazine nitrogen remained at the same binding energy indicating the interaction of Fe with nitrogen atoms derived from triazine decomposition during exfoliation of bulk CTFs rather than with triazine units themselves. XPS Fe2p spectra demonstrated the lines typical for the Fe(III) state. The authors tested the catalyst in H2O2-induced oxidation of 3,3´,5,5´-tetramethylbenzidine and showed an enhanced peroxidase-like activity, which was assigned to the ability of Fe/CTFs to decompose hydrogen peroxide with the formation of OH• radicals accelerating the reaction. Zhu et al. [91] synthesized CTFs containing N4 units via a low-temperature polycondensation between aldehyde and amidine. A BET surface area of the support corresponded to 425 m2 /g. This CTFs stabilized Fe ions loaded from iron chloride forming single-atom Fe-N4 sites. A pyrolysis was performed at 823, 923 and 1073 K. The concentration of Fe in these samples was in the range of 1.4–2.1 wt%. The formation of single-atom Fe sites was confirmed by HAADF/STEM and EXAFS. No formation of nanoparticles was observed. Except of four nitrogen atoms one oxygen atom was also attached to the Fe atom. For the samples pyrolyzed at 823, 923 and 1073 K the Fe-N distances corresponded to 2.04, 2.00 and 2.25 Å, while the Fe-O distances were equal to 1.89, 2.26 and 2.04 Å, respectively. The samples were tested in electrochemical oxygen reduction reaction. The authors found that the 2e− selectivity of the materials demonstrated the order: C-FeN4-823 (68 %) > C-FeN4-923 (41 %) > C-FeN4-1073 (20 %). These data show the importance of the pyrolysis temperature for the formation of active sites. Cui and co-authors [92] prepared a single-atom 1.6 wt% Fe catalyst supported on crystalline CTFs with a lower coordination numbers of the Fe atom to N sites than discussed above. FeCl3 was used instead of ZnCl2 for ionothermal synthesis and 2,6-pyridinedicarbonitrile was used as a monomer. The obtained Fe/CTFs nanosheets possessed a thickness of 1.6 nm. The initial single-atom site corresponded to Fe-N3 with N sites from triazine and pyridine units of CTFs. According to DFT studies the energy of the Fe atom interaction with 3 nitrogen atoms of a single CTFs sheet was about 3 eV. This catalyst showed an excellent behavior in electrocatalytic oxygen reduction reaction with a half-wave potential and onset potential up to 0.902 and 1.02 V, respectively. The authors combined operando EXAFS/XANES study with DFT calculations and showed the transformation of the Fe-N3 sites to the Fe-N2 sites due to interaction with oxygen containing intermediates during the reaction. Fe single-atom catalysts supported on CTFs represent the catalysts which could be active in thermal and electrocatalytic reactions. Similarly, to Cu/CTFs catalysts the activity of Fe/CTFs in some reactions reminds that of peroxidase enzymes. 4 Dual single-atom catalysts Usually, the mechanism of catalytic reactions involves several steps. Some steps may take place efficiently on a single-atom metal site, but for other steps another single-atom site would be preferred. Thus, a novel concept implies utilization of dual single-atom catalysts, in which two different metal single-atom sites are located closely to each other and work together as an optimized catalytic site with bifunctional properties providing a significant increase in activity and/or selectivity of the reaction [93–95]. In addition, the presence of two metal atoms in vicinity may adjust electronic properties of the sites influencing their catalytic properties. Zhang et al. [96] noticed that the support material plays a crucial role in the remarkable performance of dual single-atom catalysts. Thus, CTFs supports with high specific surface area and high content of N sites able to strongly interact with metal atoms should bring benefits to application of these supports. Ji et al. [5] indicated that single-atom catalysts with more than one metal atoms can facilitate adsorption and activation of substrate molecules, which may provide new catalytic pathways, reduce reaction energy barriers, and improve catalytic efficiency. Zhai et al. [97] presented an interesting example of such a catalyst which involves Pd and Co single-atom sites supported on CTFs for CO2 conversion to formate by hydrogenation in hydrogen in the presence of triethylamine. The CTFs support was prepared by polymerization of 2,6-pyridinedicarbonitrile by ionothermal method in the presence of ZnCl2 at 673 and then at 873 K. The authors used acetylacetonate salts of metals and obtained the loadings of Pd and Co equal to 3.17 and 2.53 wt%, respectively. The existence of two metal atoms in close proximity was confirmed by HAADF/STEM and EXAFS/XANES studies. The data indicated that the state of Pd was close to that of Pd2+, while that of Co to Co2+ and Co3+. An EXAFS peak at 2.2 Å for the Pd1−Co1/CTFs catalyst was shorter than the typical Pd−Pd distance in Pd foil, indicating the presence of Pd−Co coordination. Modelling of the EXAFS curves was performed, which indicated that the coordination numbers were equal to 1.68 Å for Pd−Co, 2.33 Å for Pd−N, and 3.12 Å for Co−N. It is important that such a structure could be realized within a single CTFs ring ( Fig. 14). This type of a dual single-atom site is related to the bonded type [98]. Yet, two other types of dual sites were discriminated earlier: bridged and non-bonded. They should demonstrate different adsorption and catalytic properties. The active sites in one catalyst could be non-uniform. The catalyst may contain also isolated single-atom sites. This should be considered for developing of structure-activity relationships [98]. Thus, a significant work is needed for controlled synthesis of a catalyst containing the most active sites to provide the highest catalytic efficiency. The authors performed hydrogenation of CO2 from air at 1 bar pressure in 1:1 ratio of CO2 to H2 and 303 K. Usually, the conditions used for this reaction are much harsher [59]. The heteronuclear Pd1−Co1/CTFs catalyst showed the best catalytic activity conversion of CO2 into formate with a turn-over-number (TON) up to 21.7, which was nearly 10 times higher than that of homonuclear Pd2/CTF catalyst. During the reaction time of 24 h the CO2 conversion reached 85 %. The authors showed that H2 could be dissociated on the Pd site, while the Co site adsorbed CO2. Unfortunately, the number of examples of studies for dual single-atom catalysts supported on CTFs is very limited. This is also the case for COFs based dual single-atom catalysts [94,99]. Design of triple single-atom catalysts could be considered as a further step [100,101]. 5 Summary and perspectives The present review shows that a broad range of reactions has been performed using single-atom metal catalysts based on CTFs supports ( Fig. 15, Table 1). These are oxidation of organic compounds, hydrogen production from formic acid, hydroformylation, transfer hydrogenation, photocatalytic N2 fixation, photoreduction of CO2, oxygen and hydrogen evolution reactions and others. Evidently, the list of the reactions will be expanded in the future. For example, the number of reactions of organic transformations over these catalysts is very limited now (Table 1). Hydrogenation reactions with molecular hydrogen are of interest since they are efficiently performed using single-atom catalysts. For example, the reaction of hydrogenation of acetylene could give a very selective production of ethylene. Heterolytic hydrogen molecule dissociation could take place on these catalysts due to the presence of metal and nitrogen atoms in proximity. Table 1 shows some characteristics of the studied single-atom catalysts supported on CTFs and demonstrates the main features of the single-atom active sites determined by EXAFS. A relatively high concentration of single-atom metal sites up to 4 wt% was reached with CTFs used as supports. This feature is important for practical applications [19] of these catalysts. Different synthesis approaches have been applied to obtain single-atom catalysts supported on CTFs. These approaches involve impregnation, ion-exchange, microwave enhanced synthesis as well as pyrolysis/ionothermal synthesis. An impregnation method is considered as a simple method for synthesis of single-atom catalysts and could be used for large-scale production. However, Zhang et al. [102] noticed that it is difficult to balance between high metal loadings and the state of single-atom. Application of impregnation did not lead to high density of surface single-atom metal sites as was obtained in the case of using CTFs for g-C3N4 [103] and N-doped carbon [11–13,103] taken as supports. This is explained by the presence of a higher number of certain N-containing sites on the CTFs surface which interact with metal containing precursors and then with single metal atoms. The interaction of the single atoms with N and C sites determines high stability of single-atom catalysts in reactions as compared to that of catalysts with nanoparticles. Earlier, using DFT calculations we determined binding energies of some metals (Cu, Au, Pd, Pt, Ru, Ni, Co) with double vacancy sites on graphene surface containing N2C2 and N4 species on the edges [9]. These values were compared with cohesive energies of metals which reflect the binding energy of a single metal atom with bulk metal. The values of cohesive energies were significantly lower. For Ni and Co they were even by a factor of 2.5 lower. These results could be considerd in relation to active single-atom sites on CTFs supports which often demonstrate the coordination number of 4 with respect to N and C atoms (Table 1). A pyrolysis/ionothermal method was used mainly for synthesis of single-atom non-noble metal catalysts supported on CTFs. This method simultaneously forms the support structure and that of the single-atom metal site and could be considered as a one-pot synthesis for large-scale applications. At the same time, Zhang et al. [102] indicated that this method demands a lot work for optimizing the experimental temperature conditions and its energy consumption is higher than that necessary for some other synthesis methods. In addition, it can provide the formation of non-uniform metal atom sites due to amorphous nature of CTFs materials. As compared to CTFs, g-C3N4 supports usually possess low specific surface areas. It is difficult to obtain this material with a specific surface area higher than 50 m2/g. The nature of the N-containing sites in CTFs and g-C3N4 could be also different providing the formation of single-atom metal sites of different structure. Thus, the Pd-N4 sites were formed on py- and bipyCTFs with the Pd-N bond length equal to 2.04 Å [38] while the coordination numbers of Pd atoms on N-doped carbon nanofibers [13] or g-C3N4 supported on reduced graphene oxide [19] were lower (∼ 3) implying the formation of Pd-N3 sites with the Pd-N bond length close to 1.98 Å. This could explain a higher activity of the Pd catalysts supported on carbon nanofibers [104] and g-C3N4 [103] in hydrogen production from formic acid. However, the Pd-N4 sites could be preferable for other reactions. Moreover, by varying the nature of the carbonitrile precursor for CTFs the nature of the Pd single-atom sites could be tuned. Thus, Pd-C2N2 and Pd-C1N3 sites are formed for CTF-1 and hatnCTF, respectively (Table 1). The activity of these sites is comparable with that of the Pd-N3 sites on carbon nanofibers and can even exceed it. Studies of dual single-atom catalysts will evidently expand since these catalysts could allow to improve the activity of some reactions. The active metal sites usually represent cations attached to four or three C and N neighbors of the support (Table 1). The abundance of electron rich sites in CTFs with lone pairs provides strong metal – support interaction. Often, the activity of a single-atom catalyst is higher than that of a metal free support or a catalyst with metal nanoparticles. One of the reasons of this is that usually the catalysts with nanoparticles can be easier poisoned by CO or by hydrocarbons leading to catalyst deactivation. Being in an isolated cationic state a supported single metal atom stabilized by the support sites is much more resistant to deactivation. This takes place due to a weaker interaction with poisons and due to decreased leaching of the active metal in a solution owing to stronger interaction with the support N sites. The structure of a single metal atom site with four N neighbors could be similar to that in phthalocyanine and porphyrin metal complexes with relatively short Metal-N bonds (< 2 Å). Alternatively, these distances could be longer indicating to the connection of two CTFs sheets via the metal atom. The three-fold attachment implies unsaturated coordination of the metal atom and possibility of easier interaction with reactant molecules. This kind of a site could be stabilized by a sole CTFs unit (Fig. 6). Reaction mechanisms over bulk and single-atom catalysts differ due to different natures of active sites [86]. Pyridinic type N sites in some CTFs supports are considered as necessary sites for some reactions working in combination with single-atom metal sites [77]. Thus, the CTFs support may participate in the reaction as not only a place for location of single-atom sites, but also as a place with nitrogen active sites. Recently, some reaction mechanisms were reviewed for single-atom catalysts and molecular complexes supported on COFs [44]. Generally, the field of reaction mechanisms demands further studies for many single-atom catalysts, and not only for those supported on CTFs. The confirmation of the presence of single atoms should be performed using several methods involving EXAFS, HAADF/STEM and XPS. Experimental in situ or operando studies would be useful to study these systems since the structure of single-atom active sites may change due to interaction with components of a reaction mixture [91,92]. This interaction may also affect the stability of active sites in a reactive solution. DFT calculations of single-atom catalysts supported on CTFs are rather limited due to complexity of Metal/CTFs systems and necessity to consider the presence of solvent in liquid phase reactions. A comparison with real systems is difficult due to amorphization/carbonization of the material prepared by ionothermal synthesis at high temperatures. In addition, a metal atom can influence the CTFs sheets distorting them. At the same time, the approaches related to DFT calculations of these systems should be expanded. Based on the mentioned reports, high activity and selectivity of metals supported on CTFs could be attributed to the nature of single-atom active sites, while other features like porosity and hydrophilicity could be important too especially for conversion of big size molecules [64,65]. The variability of CTFs precursors and conditions of the CTFs structure formation are the keys to control the pore structure, the structure of single-atom metal sites and polarity of support surface. Single-atom non-noble metal catalysts supported on CTFs were mainly studied in photocatalytic and electrocatalytic reactions. Evidently, these catalysts will be studied in the future in thermal catalytic reactions and these studies will lead to the appearance of highly active and selective non-noble metal catalysts. The knowledge obtained for electro- and photocatalysts could be useful for development of single-atom catalysts supported on CTFs for thermal catalytic reactions. Studies of dual single-atom catalysts will evidently expand since these catalysts could allow to improve the activity of some reactions. CTFs supports allow to obtain single-atom catalysts with high content of metal atoms for different catalytic applications. These catalysts possess improved properties and maximized atom utilization efficiency as compared to catalysts with supported nanoparticles and sometimes metal complexes. Yet, there are certain difficulties in commercial application of CTFs as catalysts’ supports. One of this is that upscaling of СTFs synthesis is a difficult process since using of harsh reaction conditions [21]. Another problem is that the price of some monomers can be high. Krishnaraj et al. [21] noticed that monomers should be selected with a trade-off between the performance and cost. Another opportunity would be to use a material which can be recycled and reused multiple times. CTFs are very stable materials and can be recycled. Bavykina et al. [105] reported that during using of CTFs based catalysts in a powdered form a partial loss of the catalyst upon sampling or recovery during catalyst recycling may take place. To prevent this, the authors proposed to perform shaping of the catalyst using a one-step method for the production of porous, mechanically rigid, and easy-to-handle CTFs-based spheres prepared by a phase inversion method using the polyimide Matrimid® as a binder. This approach provided accessible CTFs porosity and a high mechanical and thermal stability. The authors deposited an Ir complex on this material and showed full recyclability of the catalyst in the liquid phase reactions of CO2 hydrogenation to formic acid and in formic acid decomposition. Therefore, they noticed that as compared to the powdered CTFs based catalyst, the obtained spheres-based catalyst was more easily handled, and fully recyclable without loss of material. In another paper [106], the same authors noticed that using of a polymer for shaping the catalyst limits the reaction conditions to those were the polymer component would not be dissolved. To prevent this, they proposed to deposit films of CTFs in monoliths. The authors demonstrated that application of these catalysts allowed to prevent diffusion limitations in liquid phase which led to poor catalyst utilization. Therefore, the both proposed approaches expand the range of applicability of CTFs supports in catalytic processes and facilitate scaling up of the catalytic processes. Finally, future directions of research in the field of single-atom catalysts supported on CTFs could be proposed. These are: studies of thermal catalytic reactions using non-noble metal and Pt-based catalysts, using of the mentioned catalysts in organics transformation reactions, in hydrogenation and oxidation reactions, some of these reactions could be related to biomass valorization, increasing the metal density in these catalysts keeping the metal atomic state, design of dual and triple single-atom metal catalysts and their characterization, in situ studies of the reaction active sites and mechanisms, developing of novel methods for stabilization of CTFs preventing diffusion limitations and facilitating operations with these materials. We believe that the studies in the field of these promising materials as single-atom catalysts supported on CTFs will develop further intensively due to their unique properties and reactivities. coredata.dc:description: Covalent triazine frameworks (CTFs) are relatively novel materials and could be used as supports for single-atom metal catalysts (SACs), which attract a lot of interest during last years. The present review shows that CTFs are suitable supports for SACs for different reactions including oxidation, hydroformylation, O2 reduction, N2 fixation, CO2 photoreduction, hydrogen production, transfer and evolution. It discusses synthesis techniques and focuses on the structure of the obtained single-atom active sites including Pd, Ir, Ru, Rh, Pt, Ni, Co, Cu, and Fe atoms. It also considers some mechanisms of the mentioned reactions. The critical challenges and future perspectives for SACs based on CTFs are considered. This knowledge could be used as a base for design and engineering of single-atom active sites and will allow one to develop novel catalysts for different catalytic processes.
